title: Effect of payload on gravitational field

content.question: A payload of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="lowercase m is less than uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>m</mi></mstyle><mo><</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>M</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, is delivered to the space station. Soon after, the space station’s orbit is adjusted so that it is <math alttext="50 kilometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mtext> </mtext><mi>k</mi><mi>m</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> farther away from Earth’s surface than before. Which of the following best describes the effects of these changes on Earth’s gravitational field strength at the space station’s new location?

choices.label: The increase in mass of the space station has no effect on the field strength, and the increase in orbital radius decreases the field strength.
The increase in mass increases the field strength, and the increase in orbital radius decreases the field strength; however, the field strength decreases overall.
The increase in mass increases the field strength, and the increase in orbital radius decreases the field strength; however, the field strength increases overall.
The field strength is unchanged because there is no gravitational field in space.

content.answer: The increase in mass of the space station has no effect on the field strength, and the increase in orbital radius decreases the field strength.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
